text: These stuff can be built on web2 platforms, but without privacy they can not exist in the crypto space. With onchain private state you can build a whole set of new products

just to name some draft ideas nothing very polished

- private payroll payments 
- private auctions/price discovery tools
- private txs for onchain investment funds
- private DAO tooling ( polls + snapshot)
- KYC + AML zk credentials

I get the thought, but as a builder I really think that there is a huge space to be discovered of privacy products. Not just for the sake of being anon, but because privacy is a primitive for products that can not be built without a private state.

The root of this argument, is from a post saying "what as a builder would you want in a chain"

As a builder, I create a product users want

I will not build a privacy preserving product

First off I want to acknowledge your good faith in this debate. 

"Because it is too generalistic"- I only read the market. 
- people are willing to use apps for free, if they must give out their data 
- governments are actively pushing for a ban on privacy 
- no solution yet, except the ones which favours criminals, exists solemnly to preserve privacy 

Heck, even 99% of Thorchain atomic swap volume is used by Lazarus !

So going back to the starting point, I don't think that saying no one cares about privacy is a good way to think about products because is too generalistic. There is a whole spectrum of applications and pricing to be explored yet to arrive to the conclusion that privacy is not important

Meh, make these people choose between an ATM on the street that shouts how much cash you just withdrew and one that doesnâ€™t, everyone will pick the second. Itâ€™s a tradeoff. The balance will tilt the other way as the experience gets smoother in the long term

Anecdotally, for me right now, I would give up our current chain in a heartbeat to halve preconf time IF the ease of getting net-new crypto user funds onto the chain was equally easy and the chain was EVM equivalent plus a bunch of prerequisites on infra providers
Blocktime (or pre-conf time) is increasingly important, especially when building consumer (not prosumer) experiences

You shouldn't treat all privacy at the same level, as if sharing your personal data with instagram were the same as sharing your entire financial history with the world.
The value of privacy depends on the context you are talking about.

That take is as generalist as saying, "no one cares about crypto." Some products are better if built on blockchains, some are not. Certain products become far better when privacy is part of their features, while for others it might not matter as much

A bit in the opposite direction than @cesariooeth: 

If you talk about "hacker's paradise" and "cypherpunks" (your words in the post) then a privacy-first EVM would certainly be attractive.

An EVM where the smart contract calls and state are transparent, but where the wallet addresses are not visible. Even simply porting some proven EVM protocols onto it would be appealing.

Imagine a port of Uniswap, where you see what is being swapped, but you cannot see which wallet does it. Transparent market but truly anonymous users. And if you then consider more censorship-resistant protocols (Ajna, Liquity, etc) then you would really be in cypherpunk's land (...and in an AML nightmare! ğŸ˜…)
Yeah no, they are all the same if they are EVM equivalent

Some combination (depending on what stage of project Iâ€™m working on) of grants, liquidity, ease of access for users (onboarding fiat), infrastructure support (RPCs, stablecoins, block explorers, etc), uptime/reliability, block time
